ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze many different sources (comics, archives, scientific papers) and evaluate them based on their objectivity. I also learned how to think critically about what research gets traction and why.
Became a better writer, but also learned how to use archival sources and work with texts that are confusing or hard to read.
This class made me look at sexuality in a totally new light, and makes me think about the world differently too! My writing also has gotten a lot better, learned how to structure a paper well
Really helpful for learning about archives and especially for reading and directing scientific papers that sometimes have ethical questions.

My writing tremendously improved through this course. I also learned about a fascinating topic. If you have the opportunity to take this course, take it. This has been my favorite course at Yale so far.

I learned new insights into the human perspective of sexuality and creating a new lens of thinking about the world around me in many different aspects. I learned about world cultural differences of sexuality and different ways science contains bias. I also learned how to critically read and write in ways that I had never thought of before.

Analyzing archives, understanding the intense theory of Foucault, and articulating myself better were some of the skills I developed in this class. This course offers the opportunity for Yale students to tackle questions regarding sexuality throughout history in a nuanced manner. Students in the class will also get the chance to have discussions with authors of works read in class as well.
How to read and discuss the history of sexuality from a modern perspective.

Writing skills, the history of sexuality, analysis of discourse and academic claims. I also learned to analyze current phenomenons not only as they are but also as they have been. Their past is one of the most important aspects of their present, if not the most important.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses. It is a truly amazing course and Professor Trumpler makes it such a welcoming space. Usually I feel pretty nervous in my classes, but I felt really comfortable contributing and asking questions. She provides really helpful comments on the essays. Even the layout of the classroom facilitates learning (we sit in small groups and get to share our ideas with each other before moving to the larger class). I've become a better writer and thinker because of this class.
There are only strengths. Everything from discussions to readings to essays makes this a phenomenal course.

Professor Trumpler made class feel like a very safe, comfortable, and fun environment! Class was also not in a typical Yale classroom which made it more engaging. Readings were also very diverse and interesting, very engaging. Sometimes reading whole books (3 times) was a lot, but it made sense for the curriculum of the class and she didn't make us fully understand the entire books, so it was fair. Group discussions for about half of class time was both engaging and helped facilitate learning!
The biggest strength was the discussions for every reading. Having them in small groups for half the class was meaningful and helped make the environment more welcoming to all viewpoints.
Strengths: Great discussions, easy professor to talk to, great content. Weaknesses: None.
I truly have nothing negative to say about this course or the instructor.
Good reading materials and setup of the classroom.
Everything about the course is fantastic, from the setting, to the small-group conversations, to Professor Trumpler, to the readings and the assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! If you are given the opportunity to take this class, then take it. It has been my favorite class at Yale so far (granted it's only my second semester).
Even if you think you have no interest in anything related to sexuality, take this course. It is amazing in it's own right.

Yes!!! Great intro writing class even for STEM people, connects science, society, and sexuality in a super engaging way and changes how you view sexuality and the role of science throughout history! Professor Trumpler was an amazing, super helpful professor as well

100% take this course. If you think you would be interested at all, take it. Professor Trumpler is so wonderful and this course helps you see the world in new ways (especially the past). It doesn't have a huge workload but is engaging.
Yes, this course is great for both humanities and stem majors.

I would recommend this course immediately to so many people. I think it is a great intro to WGSS courses and also gives you a great foundation for looking at the world in a different way. I think this is a foundational class that should be more widely offered.

I would totally recommend this class to another student! Professor Trumpler is so detailed in the feedback that she gives you on your essays, and the way she is so intentional in the development of class material is outstanding! I learned so much from this class and it is a great choice for first'years that need a writing credit.
Yes, it opened my eyes and reframed how I view sexuality and the history of science.

Definitely. There are many misinformed and superficial claims about sexuality in media nowadays. This course provides a fantastic recount of the developments in the discourse on sexuality and how it changed our perceptions of what something sexual or what sex is.
